titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

div.p: Some, it may be, will knit the Brow, if I should say, that even Holy Scripture itself, sometimes requires an astronomical Interpreter: who else shall…decide the controversy about the Retrocession of the Shadow upon the Dial of Ahaz? When without a miracle that might be many ways done by the meer Fabrick of the Dial…Neither need we fear to diminish a Miracle by explaining it: this Retrocession of the Sun was given as a Sign, so was the Rainbow, which had it appear'd never since, had been miraculous.

body.p: Sir Christopher Wren was well beyond the obsessions of the XVIIth century when he expressed himself thus in 1657, when he was but 25. I think I will preach about him to the Freemasons on April 15th.
Clayton and I motored to the North Eastern County School, and there, in the school chapel, I confirmed 57 boys. After having tea with a large company of parents & boys, we returned to Auckland.

I read through Wren's Parentalia with a view to estimating the homiletic value of the great Man's Life and Character. On the whole I incline to thing that I "struck oil". He was certainly a 'miracle of a man'.
